00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 PGnumericevaluators.pl - Macros that generate numeric answer evaluators.
00020 
00021 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00022 
00023     ANS(num_cmp($answer_or_answer_array_ref, %options_hash));
00024     
00025     ANS(std_num_cmp($correctAnswer, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00026     ANS(std_num_cmp_abs($correctAnswer, $absTol, $format));
00027     ANS(std_num_cmp_list($relTol, $format, @answerList));
00028     ANS(std_num_cmp_abs_list($absTol, $format, @answerList));
00029     
00030     ANS(arith_num_cmp($correctAnswer, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00031     ANS(arith_num_cmp_abs($correctAnswer, $absTol, $format));
00032     ANS(arith_num_cmp_list($relTol, $format, @answerList));
00033     ANS(arith_num_cmp_abs_list($absTol, $format, @answerList));
00034     
00035     ANS(strict_num_cmp($correctAnswer, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00036     ANS(strict_num_cmp_abs($correctAnswer, $absTol, $format));
00037     ANS(strict_num_cmp_list($relTol, $format, @answerList));
00038     ANS(strict_num_cmp_abs_list($absTol, $format, @answerList));
00039     
00040     ANS(frac_num_cmp($correctAnswer, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00041     ANS(frac_num_cmp_abs($correctAnswer, $absTol, $format));
00042     ANS(frac_num_cmp_list($relTol, $format, @answerList));
00043     ANS(frac_num_cmp_abs_list($absTol, $format, @answerList));
00044 
00045 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00046 
00047 Numeric answer evaluators take in a numerical answer, compare it to the correct
00048 answer, and return a score. In addition, they can choose to accept or reject an
00049 answer based on its format, closeness to the correct answer, and other criteria.
00050 
00051 The general numeric answer evaluator is num_cmp(). It takes a hash of named
00052 options as parameters. There are also sixteen specific "mode"_num_cmp() answer
00053 evaluators for use in common situations which feature a simplified syntax.
00054 
00055 =head2 MathObjects and answer evaluators
00056 
00057 The MathObjects system provides $obj->cmp() methods that produce answer
00058 evaluators for a wide variety of answer types. num_cmp() has been rewritten to
00059 use the appropriate MathObject to produce the answer evaluator. It is
00060 recommended that you use the MathObjects cmp() methods directly if possible.
00061 
00062 =cut
00063 
00064 BEGIN { be_strict() }
00065 
00066 # Until we get the PG cacheing business sorted out, we need to use
00067 # PG_restricted_eval to get the correct values for some(?) PG environment
00068 # variables. We do this once here and place the values in lexicals for later
00069 # access.
00070 my $CA;
00071 my $Context;
00072 my $numAbsTolDefault;
00073 my $numFormatDefault;
00074 my $numRelPercentTolDefault;
00075 my $numZeroLevelDefault;
00076 my $numZeroLevelTolDefault;
00077 my $useOldAnswerMacros;
00078 my $user_context;
00079 sub _PGnumericevaluators_init {
00080     $CA                      = PG_restricted_eval(q/$CA/);
00081     $numAbsTolDefault        = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{numAbsTolDefault}/);
00082     $numFormatDefault        = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{numFormatDefault}/);
00083     $numRelPercentTolDefault = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{numRelPercentTolDefault}/);
00084     $numZeroLevelDefault     = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{numZeroLevelDefault}/);
00085     $numZeroLevelTolDefault  = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{numZeroLevelTolDefault}/);
00086     $useOldAnswerMacros      = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{useOldAnswerMacros}/);
00087     unless ($useOldAnswerMacros) {
00088         $user_context = PG_restricted_eval(q/\%context/);
00089         $Context = sub { Parser::Context->current($user_context, @_) };
00090     }
00091 }
00092 
00093 =head1 num_cmp
00094 
00095     ANS(num_cmp($answer_or_answer_array_ref, %options));
00096 
00097 num_cmp() returns one or more answer evaluators (subroutine references) that
00098 compare the student's answer to a numeric value. Evaluation options are
00099 specified as items in the %options hash. This can make for more readable code
00100 than using the "mode"_num_cmp() style, but some people find one or the other
00101 easier to remember.
00102 
00103 =head2 Options
00104 
00105 $answer_or_answer_array_ref can either be a scalar containing a numeric value or
00106 a reference to an array of numeric scalars. If multiple answers are provided,
00107 num_cmp() will return a list of answer evaluators, one for each answer
00108 specified. %options is a hash containing options that affect the way the
00109 comparison is performed. All hash items are optional. Allowed options are:
00110 
00111 =over
00112 
00113 =item mode
00114 
00115 This determines the allowable methods for entering an answer. Answers which do
00116 not meet this requirement will be graded as incorrect, regardless of their
00117 numerical value. The recognized modes are:
00118 
00119 =over
00120 
00121 =item std (default)
00122 
00123 The default mode allows any expression which evaluates to a number, including
00124 those using elementary functions like sin() and exp(), as well as the operations
00125 of arithmetic (+, -, *, /, and ^).
00126 
00127 =item strict
00128 
00129 Only decimal numbers are allowed.
00130 
00131 =item frac
00132 
00133 Only whole numbers and fractions are allowed.
00134 
00135 =item arith
00136 
00137 Arithmetic expressions are allowed, but no functions.
00138 
00139 =back
00140 
00141 Note that all modes allow the use of "pi" and "e" as constants, and also the use
00142 of "E" to represent scientific notation.
00143 
00144 =item format
00145 
00146 The format to use when displaying the correct and submitted answers. This has no
00147 effect on how answers are evaluated; it is only for cosmetic purposes. The
00148 formatting syntax is the same as Perl uses for the sprintf() function. Format
00149 strings are of the form '%m.nx' or '%m.nx#', where m and n are described below,
00150 and x is a formatter.
00151 
00152 Esentially, m is the minimum length of the field (make this negative to
00153 left-justify). Note that the decimal point counts as a character when
00154 determining the field width. If m begins with a zero, the number will be padded
00155 with zeros instead of spaces to fit the field.
00156 
00157 The precision specifier (n) works differently depending on which formatter you
00158 are using. For d, i, o, u, x and X formatters (non-floating point formatters), n
00159 is the minimum number of digits to display. For e and f, it is the number of
00160 digits that appear after the decimal point (extra digits will be rounded;
00161 insufficient digits will be padded with spaces--see '#' below). For g, it is the
00162 number of significant digits to display.
00163 
00164 The full list of formatters can be found in the manpage for printf(3), or by
00165 typing "perldoc -f sprintf" at a terminal prompt. The following is a brief
00166 summary of the most frequent formatters:
00167 
00168     %d     decimal number
00169     %ld    long decimal number
00170     %u     unsigned decimal number
00171     %lu    long unsigned decimal number
00172     %x     hexadecimal number
00173     %o     octal number
00174     %e     floating point number in scientific notation
00175     %f     floating point number
00176     %g     either %e or %f, whichever takes less space
00177 
00178 Technically, %g will use %e if the exponent is less than -4 or greater than or
00179 equal to the precision. Trailing zeros are removed in this mode.
00180 
00181 If the format string ends in '#', trailing zeros will be removed in the decimal
00182 part. Note that this is not a standard syntax; it is handled internally by
00183 WeBWorK and not by Perl (although this should not be a concern to end users).
00184 The default format is '%0.5f#', which displays as a floating point number with 5
00185 digits of precision and no trailing zeros. Other useful format strings might be
00186 '%0.2f' for displaying dollar amounts, or '%010d' to display an integer with
00187 leading zeros. Setting format to an empty string ( '' ) means no formatting will
00188 be used; this will show 'arbitrary' precision floating points.
00189 
00190 =item tol
00191 
00192 An absolute tolerance value. The student answer must be a fixed distance from
00193 the correct answer to qualify. For example, an absolute tolerance of 5 means
00194 that any number which is +-5 of the correct answer qualifies as correct. abstol
00195 is accepted as a synonym for tol.
00196 
00197 =item relTol
00198 
00199 A relative tolerance. Relative tolerances are given in percentages. A relative
00200 tolerance of 1 indicates that the student answer must be within 1% of the
00201 correct answer to qualify as correct. In other words, a student answer is
00202 correct when
00203 
00204     abs(studentAnswer - correctAnswer) <= abs(.01*relTol*correctAnswer)
00205 
00206 tol and relTol are mutually exclusive. reltol is also accpeted as a synonym for
00207 relTol.
00208 
00209 =item zeroLevel, zeroLevelTol
00210 
00211 zeroLevel and zeroLevelTol specify a alternative absolute tolerance to use when
00212 the correct answer is very close to zero.
00213 
00214 If the correct answer has an absolute value less than or equal to zeroLevel,
00215 then the student answer must be, in absolute terms, within zeroLevelTol of
00216 correctAnswer, i.e.,
00217 
00218     abs(studentAnswer - correctAnswer) <= zeroLevelTol
00219 
00220 In other words, if the correct answer is very near zero, an absolute tolerance
00221 will be used. One must do this to handle floating point answers very near zero,
00222 because of the inaccuracy of floating point arithmetic. However, the default
00223 values are almost always adequate.
00224 
00225 =item units
00226 
00227 A string representing the units of the correct answer. If specified, the student
00228 answer must include these units. The strings and units options are mutually
00229 exclusive.
00230 
00231 =item strings
00232 
00233 A reference to an array of strings which are valid (but incorrect) answers. This
00234 prevents non-numeric entries like "NaN" or "None" from causing a syntax error.
00235 The strings and units options are mutually exclusive.
00236 
00237 =item debug
00238 
00239 If set to 1, extra debugging information will be output.
00240 
00241 =back
00242 
00243 =head2 Examples
00244 
00245     # correct answer is 5, using defaults for all options
00246     num_cmp(5);
00247 
00248     # correct answers are 5, 6, and 7, using defaults for all options
00249     num_cmp([5,6,7]);
00250 
00251     # correct answer is 5, mode is strict
00252     num_cmp(5, mode=>'strict');
00253 
00254     # correct answers are 5 and 6, both with 5% relative tolerance
00255     num_cmp([5,6], relTol=>5);
00256 
00257     # correct answer is 6, "Inf", "Minf", and "NaN" recognized as valid, but
00258     # incorrect answers.
00259     num_cmp(6, strings=>["Inf", "Minf", "NaN"]);
00260 
00261     # correct answer is "-INF", "INF" and numerical expressions recognized as
00262     # valid, but incorrect answers.
00263     num_cmp("-INF", strings => ["INF", "-INF"]);
00264 
00265 =cut
00266 
00267 sub num_cmp {
00268     my $correctAnswer = shift @_;
00269     $CA = $correctAnswer;
00270     my @opt = @_;
00271     my %out_options;
00272 
00273 #########################################################################
00274 # Retain this first check for backword compatibility.  Allows input of the form
00275 # num_cmp($ans, 1, '%0.5f') but warns against it
00276 #########################################################################
00277     my %known_options = (
00278                     'mode'          =>  'std',
00279                     'format'        =>  $numFormatDefault,
00280                     'tol'           =>  $numAbsTolDefault,
00281                     'relTol'        =>  $numRelPercentTolDefault,
00282                     'units'         =>  undef,
00283                     'strings'       =>  undef,
00284                     'zeroLevel'     =>  $numZeroLevelDefault,
00285                     'zeroLevelTol'  =>  $numZeroLevelTolDefault,
00286                     'tolType'       =>  'relative',
00287                     'tolerance'     =>  1,
00288                     'reltol'        =>  undef,          #alternate spelling
00289                     'unit'          =>  undef,          #alternate spelling
00290                     'debug'         =>  0
00291         );
00292 
00293     my @output_list;
00294     my( $relPercentTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol) = @opt;
00295 
00296     unless( ref($correctAnswer) eq 'ARRAY' || scalar( @opt ) == 0 ||
00297               ( defined($opt[0]) and exists $known_options{$opt[0]} ) ) {
00298         # unless the first parameter is a list of arrays
00299         # or the second parameter is a known option or
00300         # no options were used,
00301         # use the old num_cmp which does not use options, but has inputs
00302         # $relPercentTol,$format,$zeroLevel,$zeroLevelTol
00303         warn "This method of using num_cmp() is deprecated. Please rewrite this" .
00304                     " problem using the options style of parameter passing (or" .
00305                     " check that your first option is spelled correctly).";
00306 
00307         %out_options = (    'relTol'        => $relPercentTol,
00308                     'format'        => $format,
00309                     'zeroLevel'     => $zeroLevel,
00310                     'zeroLevelTol'  => $zeroLevelTol,
00311                     'mode'          => 'std'
00312         );
00313     }
00314 
00315 #########################################################################
00316 # Now handle the options assuming they are entered in the form
00317 # num_cmp($ans, relTol=>1, format=>'%0.5f')
00318 #########################################################################
00319     %out_options = @opt;
00320     assign_option_aliases( \%out_options,
00321                 'reltol'    =>      'relTol',
00322                 'unit'      =>      'units',
00323                 'abstol'    =>      'tol',
00324                 );
00325 
00326     set_default_options( \%out_options,
00327                  'tolType'      =>  (defined($out_options{'tol'}) ) ? 'absolute' : 'relative',  # the existence of "tol" means that we use absolute tolerance mode
00328                  'tolerance'    =>  (defined($out_options{'tolType'}) && $out_options{'tolType'} eq 'absolute' ) ? $numAbsTolDefault : $numRelPercentTolDefault,  # relative tolerance is the default
00329                  'mode'         =>  'std',
00330                  'format'       =>  $numFormatDefault,
00331                  'tol'          =>  undef,
00332                  'relTol'       =>  undef,
00333                  'units'        =>  undef,
00334                  'strings'      =>  undef,
00335                  'zeroLevel'    =>  $numZeroLevelDefault,
00336                  'zeroLevelTol' =>  $numZeroLevelTolDefault,
00337                  'debug'        =>  0,
00338     );
00339 
00340     # can't use both units and strings
00341     if( defined( $out_options{'units'} ) && defined( $out_options{'strings'} ) ) {
00342         warn "Can't use both 'units' and 'strings' in the same problem " .
00343         "(check your parameters to num_cmp() )";
00344     }
00345 
00346     # absolute tolType and relTol are incompatible. So are relative tolType and tol
00347     if( defined( $out_options{'relTol'} ) &&  $out_options{'tolType'} eq 'absolute' )  {
00348         warn "The 'tolType' 'absolute' is not compatible with 'relTol' " .
00349         "(check your parameters to num_cmp() )";
00350     }
00351     if( defined( $out_options{'tol'} ) &&  $out_options{'tolType'} eq 'relative' )  {
00352         warn "The 'tolType' 'relative' is not compatible with 'tol' " .
00353         "(check your parameters to num_cmp() )";
00354     }
00355 
00356 
00357     # Handle legacy options
00358     if ($out_options{tolType} eq 'absolute')   {
00359         $out_options{'tolerance'}=$out_options{'tol'} if defined($out_options{'tol'});
00360         delete($out_options{'relTol'}) if exists( $out_options{'relTol'} );
00361     } else {
00362         $out_options{'tolerance'}=$out_options{'relTol'} if defined($out_options{'relTol'});
00363         # delete($out_options{'tol'}) if exists( $out_options{'tol'} );
00364     }
00365     # end legacy options
00366 
00367     # thread over lists
00368     my @ans_list = ();
00369 
00370     if ( ref($correctAnswer) eq 'ARRAY' ) {
00371         @ans_list = @{$correctAnswer};
00372     }
00373     else { push( @ans_list, $correctAnswer );
00374     }
00375 
00376     # produce answer evaluators
00377     foreach my $ans (@ans_list) {
00378         if( defined( $out_options{'units'} ) ) {
00379             $ans = "$ans $out_options{'units'}";
00380 
00381             push( @output_list, NUM_CMP(    
00382                             'correctAnswer' =>  $ans,
00383                             'tolerance'     =>  $out_options{'tolerance'},
00384                             'tolType'       =>  $out_options{'tolType'},
00385                             'format'        =>  $out_options{'format'},
00386                             'mode'          =>  $out_options{'mode'},
00387                             'zeroLevel'     =>  $out_options{'zeroLevel'},
00388                             'zeroLevelTol'  =>  $out_options{'zeroLevelTol'},
00389                             'debug'         =>  $out_options{'debug'},
00390                             'units'         =>  $out_options{'units'},
00391                   )
00392             );
00393         } elsif( defined( $out_options{'strings'} ) ) {
00394 
00395 
00396             push( @output_list, NUM_CMP(    
00397                             'correctAnswer' =>  $ans,
00398                             'tolerance'     =>  $out_options{tolerance},
00399                             'tolType'       =>  $out_options{tolType},
00400                             'format'        =>  $out_options{'format'},
00401                             'mode'          =>  $out_options{'mode'},
00402                             'zeroLevel'     =>  $out_options{'zeroLevel'},
00403                             'zeroLevelTol'  =>  $out_options{'zeroLevelTol'},
00404                             'debug'         =>  $out_options{'debug'},
00405                             'strings'       =>  $out_options{'strings'},
00406                  )
00407                  );
00408         } else {
00409             push(@output_list,
00410                 NUM_CMP(    
00411                     'correctAnswer' =>  $ans,
00412                     'tolerance'     =>  $out_options{tolerance},
00413                     'tolType'       =>  $out_options{tolType},
00414                     'format'        =>  $out_options{'format'},
00415                     'mode'          =>  $out_options{'mode'},
00416                     'zeroLevel'     =>  $out_options{'zeroLevel'},
00417                     'zeroLevelTol'  =>  $out_options{'zeroLevelTol'},
00418                     'debug'         =>  $out_options{'debug'},
00419                 ),
00420             );
00421         }
00422     }
00423 
00424     return (wantarray) ? @output_list : $output_list[0];
00425 }
00426 
00427 #legacy code for compatability purposes
00428 sub num_rel_cmp {       # compare numbers
00429     std_num_cmp( @_ );
00430 }
00431 
00432 =head1 "mode"_num_cmp() functions
00433 
00434 There are 16 functions that provide simplified interfaces to num_cmp(). They are
00435 organized into four groups, based on the number of answers accpeted (single or
00436 list) and whether relative or absolute tolerances are used. Each group contains
00437 four functions, one for each evaluation mode. See the mode option to num_cmp()
00438 above for details about each mode.
00439 
00440      GROUP:|    "normal"    |       "list"        |       "abs"        |        "abs_list"       |
00441            | single answer  |   list of answers   |   single answer    |     list of answers     |
00442     MODE:  | relative tol.  | relative tolerance  | absolute tolerance |    absolute tolerance   |
00443     -------+----------------+---------------------+--------------------+-------------------------+
00444        std |    std_num_cmp |    std_num_cmp_list |    std_num_cmp_abs |    std_num_cmp_abs_list |
00445       frac |   frac_num_cmp |   frac_num_cmp_list |   frac_num_cmp_abs |   frac_num_cmp_abs_list |
00446     strict | strict_num_cmp | strict_num_cmp_list | strict_num_cmp_abs | strict_num_cmp_abs_list |
00447      arith |  arith_num_cmp |  arith_num_cmp_list |  arith_num_cmp_abs |  arith_num_cmp_abs_list |
00448 
00449 The functions in each group take the same arguments.
00450 
00451 =head2 The normal group
00452 
00453     ANS(std_num_cmp($correctAnswer, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00454     ANS(arith_num_cmp($correctAnswer, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00455     ANS(strict_num_cmp($correctAnswer, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00456     ANS(frac_num_cmp($correctAnswer, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00457 
00458 This group of functions produces answer evaluators for a single correct answer
00459 using relative tolerances. The first argument, $correctAnswer, is required. The
00460 rest are optional. The arguments are equivalent to the identically-named options
00461 to num_cmp(), above.
00462 
00463 =head2 The list group
00464 
00465     ANS(std_num_cmp_list($relTol, $format, @answerList));
00466     ANS(arith_num_cmp_list($relTol, $format, @answerList));
00467     ANS(strict_num_cmp_list($relTol, $format, @answerList));
00468     ANS(frac_num_cmp_list($relTol, $format, @answerList));
00469 
00470 This group of functions produces answer evaluators for a list of correct answers
00471 using relative tolerances. $relTol and $format are equivelent to the
00472 identically-named options to num_cmp() above. @answerList must contain one or
00473 more correct answers. A list of answer evaluators is returned, one for each
00474 answer provided in @answerList. All answer returned evaluators will use the
00475 relative tolerance and format specified.
00476 
00477 =head2 The abs group
00478 
00479     ANS(std_num_cmp_abs($correctAnswer, $absTol, $format));
00480     ANS(arith_num_cmp_abs($correctAnswer, $absTol, $format));
00481     ANS(strict_num_cmp_abs($correctAnswer, $absTol, $format));
00482     ANS(frac_num_cmp_abs($correctAnswer, $absTol, $format));
00483 
00484 This group of functions produces answer evaluators for a single correct answer
00485 using absolute tolerances. The first argument, $correctAnswer, is required. The
00486 rest are optional. The arguments are equivalent to the identically-named options
00487 to num_cmp(), above.
00488 
00489 =head2 The abs_list group
00490 
00491     ANS(std_num_cmp_abs_list($absTol, $format, @answerList));
00492     ANS(arith_num_cmp_abs_list($absTol, $format, @answerList));
00493     ANS(strict_num_cmp_abs_list($absTol, $format, @answerList));
00494     ANS(frac_num_cmp_abs_list($absTol, $format, @answerList));
00495 
00496 This group of functions produces answer evaluators for a list of correct answers
00497 using absolute tolerances. $absTol and $format are equivelent to the
00498 identically-named options to num_cmp() above. @answerList must contain one or
00499 more correct answers. A list of answer evaluators is returned, one for each
00500 answer provided in @answerList. All answer returned evaluators will use the
00501 absolute tolerance and format specified.
00502 
00503 =head2 Examples
00504 
00505     # The student answer must be a number in decimal or scientific notation
00506     # which is within .1 percent of 3.14159. This assumes
00507     # $numRelPercentTolDefault has been set to .1.
00508     ANS(strict_num_cmp(3.14159));
00509 
00510     # The student answer must be a number within .01 percent of $answer (e.g. #
00511     3.14159 if $answer is 3.14159 or $answer is "pi" or $answer is 4*atan(1)).
00512     ANS(strict_num_cmp($answer, .01));
00513 
00514     # The student answer can be a number or fraction, e.g. 2/3.
00515     ANS(frac_num_cmp($answer)); # or
00516     ANS(frac_num_cmp($answer, .01));
00517 
00518     # The student answer can be an arithmetic expression, e.g. (2+3)/7-2^.5 .
00519     ANS(arith_num_cmp($answer)); # or
00520     ANS(arith_num_cmp($answer, .01));
00521 
00522     # The student answer can contain elementary functions, e.g. sin(.3+pi/2)
00523     ANS(std_num_cmp($answer)); # or
00524     ANS(std_num_cmp( $answer, .01));
00525 
00526 =cut
00527 
00528 sub std_num_cmp {                       # compare numbers allowing use of elementary functions
00529     my ( $correctAnswer, $relPercentTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol ) = @_;
00530 
00531     my %options = ( 'relTol'        =>  $relPercentTol,
00532                     'format'        =>  $format,
00533                     'zeroLevel'     =>  $zeroLevel,
00534                     'zeroLevelTol'  =>  $zeroLevelTol
00535     );
00536 
00537     set_default_options( \%options,
00538              'tolType'      =>  'relative',
00539              'tolerance'    =>  $numRelPercentTolDefault,
00540              'mode'         =>  'std',
00541              'format'       =>  $numFormatDefault,
00542              'relTol'       =>  $numRelPercentTolDefault,
00543              'zeroLevel'    =>  $numZeroLevelDefault,
00544              'zeroLevelTol' =>  $numZeroLevelTolDefault,
00545              'debug'        =>  0,
00546     );
00547 
00548     num_cmp([$correctAnswer], %options);
00549 }
00550 
00551 ##  Similar to std_num_cmp but accepts a list of numbers in the form
00552 ##  std_num_cmp_list(relpercentTol,format,ans1,ans2,ans3,...)
00553 ##  format is of the form "%10.3g" or "", i.e., a format suitable for sprintf(). Use "" for default
00554 ##  You must enter a format and tolerance
00555 
00556 sub std_num_cmp_list {
00557     my ( $relPercentTol, $format, @answerList) = @_;
00558 
00559     my %options = ( 'relTol'    =>      $relPercentTol,
00560                     'format'    =>      $format,
00561     );
00562 
00563     set_default_options( \%options,
00564                  'tolType'      =>      'relative',
00565                  'tolerance'    =>      $numRelPercentTolDefault,
00566                  'mode'         =>      'std',
00567                  'format'       =>      $numFormatDefault,
00568                  'relTol'       =>      $numRelPercentTolDefault,
00569                  'zeroLevel'    =>      $numZeroLevelDefault,
00570                  'zeroLevelTol' =>      $numZeroLevelTolDefault,
00571                  'debug'        =>      0,
00572     );
00573 
00574     num_cmp(\@answerList, %options);
00575 
00576 }
00577

00581                 'format'     => $format
00582     );
00583 
00584     set_default_options (\%options,
00585                  'tolType'      =>      'absolute',
00586                  'tolerance'    =>      $absTol,
00587                  'mode'         =>      'std',
00588                  'format'       =>      $numFormatDefault,
00589                  'zeroLevel'    =>      0,
00590                  'zeroLevelTol' =>      0,
00591                  'debug'        =>      0,
00592     );
00593 
00594     num_cmp([$correctAnswer], %options);
00595 }

00881 
00882 =head1 Miscellaneous functions
00883 
00884 =head2 [DEPRECATED] numerical_compare_with_units
00885 
00886     ANS(numerical_compare_with_units($correct_ans_with_units, %options))    
00887 
00888 This function is deprecated. Use num_cmp with the units option instead:
00889 
00890     ANS(num_cmp($correct_ans, units=>$units));
00891 
00892 =cut
00893 
00894 ## sub numerical_compare_with_units
00895 ## Compares a number with units
00896 ## Deprecated; use num_cmp()
00897 ##
00898 ## IN:  a string which includes the numerical answer and the units
00899 ##      a hash with the following keys (all optional):
00900 ##          mode        --  'std', 'frac', 'arith', or 'strict'
00901 ##          format      --  the format to use when displaying the answer
00902 ##          tol     --  an absolute tolerance, or
00903 ##          relTol      --  a relative tolerance
00904 ##          zeroLevel   --  if the correct answer is this close to zero, then zeroLevelTol applies
00905 ##          zeroLevelTol    --  absolute tolerance to allow when correct answer is close to zero
00906 
00907 # This mode is depricated.  send input through num_cmp -- it can handle units.
00908 
00909 sub numerical_compare_with_units {
00910     my $correct_answer = shift;  # the answer is a string which includes both the numerical answer and the units.
00911     my %options = @_;        # all of the other inputs are (key value) pairs
00912 
00913     # Prepare the correct answer
00914     $correct_answer = str_filters( $correct_answer, 'trim_whitespace' );
00915 
00916     # it surprises me that the match below works since the first .* is greedy.
00917     my ($correct_num_answer, $correct_units) = $correct_answer =~ /^(.*)\s+([^\s]*)$/;
00918     $options{units} = $correct_units;
00919 
00920     num_cmp($correct_num_answer, %options);
00921 }
00922 
00923 =head2 [DEPRECATED] std_num_str_cmp()
00924 
00925     ANS(std_num_str_cmp($correctAnswer, $ra_legalStrings, $relTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol))
00926 
00927 This function is deprecated. Use num_cmp() with the strings option instead:
00928 
00929     ANS(num_cmp($correctAnswer, strings=>$ra_legalStrings, ...));
00930 
00931 =cut
00932 
00933 sub std_num_str_cmp {
00934     my ( $correctAnswer, $ra_legalStrings, $relpercentTol, $format, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol ) = @_;
00935     # warn ('This method is depreciated.  Use num_cmp instead.');
00936     return num_cmp ($correctAnswer, strings=>$ra_legalStrings, relTol=>$relpercentTol, format=>$format,
00937         zeroLevel=>$zeroLevel, zeroLevelTol=>$zeroLevelTol);
00938 }
00939 
00940 sub NUM_CMP {                              # low level numeric compare (now uses Parser)
00941     return ORIGINAL_NUM_CMP(@_)
00942       if $main::useOldAnswerMacros;
00943     my %num_params = @_;
00944 
00945     #
00946     #  check for required parameters
00947     #
00948     my @keys = qw(correctAnswer tolerance tolType format mode zeroLevel zeroLevelTol debug);
00949     foreach my $key (@keys) {
00950         warn( "$key must be defined in options when calling NUM_CMP" )
00951           unless defined($num_params{$key});
00952     }
00953 
00954     my $correctAnswer = $num_params{correctAnswer};
00955     my $mode          = $num_params{mode};
00956     my %options       = (debug => $num_params{debug});
00957 
00958     #
00959     #  Hack to fix up exponential notation in correct answer
00960     #  (e.g., perl will pass .0000001 as 1e-07).
00961     #
00962     $correctAnswer = uc($correctAnswer)
00963       if $correctAnswer =~ m/e/ && Value::isNumber($correctAnswer);
00964 
00965     #
00966     #  Get an apppropriate context based on the mode
00967     #
00968     my $context;
00969     for ($mode) {
00970       /^strict$/i and do {
00971         $context = Parser::Context->getCopy($user_context,"LimitedNumeric");
00972         last;
00973       };
00974       /^arith$/i  and do {
00975         $context = Parser::Context->getCopy($user_context,"LegacyNumeric");
00976         $context->functions->disable('All');
00977         last;
00978       };
00979       /^frac$/i   and do {
00980         $context = Parser::Context->getCopy($user_context,"LimitedNumeric-Fraction");
00981         last;
00982       };
00983 
00984       # default
00985       $context = Parser::Context->getCopy($user_context,"LegacyNumeric");
00986     }
00987     $context->{format}{number} = $num_params{'format'};
00988     $context->strings->clear;
00989     #  FIXME:  should clear variables as well? Copy them from the current context?
00990     
00991     #
00992     #  Add the strings to the context
00993     #
00994     if ($num_params{strings}) {
00995       foreach my $string (@{$num_params{strings}}) {
00996         my %tex = ($string =~ m/^(-?)inf(inity)?$/i)? (TeX => "$1\\infty"): ();
00997         %tex = (TeX => "-\\infty") if uc($string) eq "MINF";
00998         $context->strings->add(uc($string) => {%tex})
00999           unless $context->strings->get(uc($string));
01000       }
01001     }
01002 
01003     #
01004     #  Set the tolerances
01005     #
01006     if ($num_params{tolType} eq 'absolute') {
01007       $context->flags->set(
01008         tolerance => $num_params{tolerance},
01009         tolType => 'absolute',
01010       );
01011     } else {
01012       $context->flags->set(
01013         tolerance => .01*$num_params{tolerance},
01014         tolType => 'relative',
01015       );
01016     }
01017     $context->flags->set(
01018       zeroLevel => $num_params{zeroLevel},
01019       zeroLevelTol => $num_params{zeroLevelTol},
01020     );
01021 
01022     #
01023     #  Get the proper Parser object for the professor's answer
01024     #  using the initialized context
01025     #
01026     my $oldContext = &$Context(); &$Context($context); my $r;
01027     if ($num_params{units}) {
01028       $r = new Parser::Legacy::NumberWithUnits($correctAnswer);
01029           $options{rh_correct_units} = $num_params{units};
01030     } else {
01031       $r = Value::Formula->new($correctAnswer);
01032       die "The professor's answer can't be a formula" unless $r->isConstant;
01033       $r = $r->eval; $r = new Value::Real($r) unless Value::class($r) eq 'String';
01034       $r->{correct_ans} = $correctAnswer;
01035       if ($mode eq 'phase_pi') {
01036         my $pi = 4*atan2(1,1);
01037         while ($r >  $pi/2) {$r -= $pi}
01038         while ($r < -$pi/2) {$r += $pi}
01039       }
01040     }
01041     #
01042     #  Get the answer checker from the parser object
01043     #
01044     my $cmp = $r->cmp(%options);
01045     $cmp->install_pre_filter(sub {
01046       my $rh_ans = shift;
01047       $rh_ans->{original_student_ans} = $rh_ans->{student_ans};
01048       $rh_ans->{original_correct_ans} = $rh_ans->{correct_ans};
01049       return $rh_ans;
01050     });
01051     $cmp->install_post_filter(sub {
01052       my $rh_ans = shift;
01053       $rh_ans->{student_ans} = $rh_ans->{student_value}->string
01054         if ref($rh_ans->{student_value});
01055       return $rh_ans;
01056     });
01057     &$Context($oldContext);
01058 
01059     return $cmp;
01060 }
01061 
01062 #
01063 #  The original version, for backward compatibility
01064 #  (can be removed when the Parser-based version is more fully tested.)
01065 #
01066 sub ORIGINAL_NUM_CMP {      # low level numeric compare
01067     my %num_params = @_;
01068     # WARN_MESSAGE("Using old ORIGINAL_NUM_CMP function.");
01069     my @keys = qw ( correctAnswer tolerance tolType format mode zeroLevel zeroLevelTol debug );
01070     foreach my $key (@keys) {
01071         warn "$key must be defined in options when calling NUM_CMP" unless defined ($num_params{$key});
01072     }
01073 
01074     my $correctAnswer   =   $num_params{'correctAnswer'};
01075     my $format          =   $num_params{'format'};
01076     my $mode            =   $num_params{'mode'};
01077 
01078     if( $num_params{tolType} eq 'relative' ) {
01079         $num_params{'tolerance'} = .01*$num_params{'tolerance'};
01080     }
01081 
01082     my $formattedCorrectAnswer;
01083     my $correct_units;
01084     my $correct_num_answer;
01085     my %correct_units;
01086     my $corrAnswerIsString = 0;
01087 
01088 
01089     if (defined($num_params{units}) && $num_params{units}) {
01090         $correctAnswer  = str_filters( $correctAnswer, 'trim_whitespace' );
01091                         # units are in form stuff space units where units contains no spaces.
01092 
01093         ($correct_num_answer, $correct_units) = $correctAnswer =~ /^(.*)\s+([^\s]*)$/;
01094         %correct_units = Units::evaluate_units($correct_units);
01095         if ( defined( $correct_units{'ERROR'} ) ) {
01096              warn ("ERROR: The answer \"$correctAnswer\" in the problem definition cannot be parsed:\n" .
01097                 "$correct_units{'ERROR'}\n");
01098         }
01099         # $formattedCorrectAnswer = spf($correct_num_answer,$num_params{'format'}) . " $correct_units";
01100         $formattedCorrectAnswer = prfmt($correct_num_answer,$num_params{'format'}) . " $correct_units";
01101 
01102     } elsif (defined($num_params{strings}) && $num_params{strings}) {
01103         my $legalString = '';
01104         my @legalStrings = @{$num_params{strings}};
01105         $correct_num_answer = $correctAnswer;
01106         $formattedCorrectAnswer = $correctAnswer;
01107         foreach $legalString (@legalStrings) {
01108             if ( uc($correctAnswer) eq uc($legalString) ) {
01109                 $corrAnswerIsString = 1;
01110 
01111                 last;
01112             }
01113         }         ## at this point $corrAnswerIsString = 0 iff correct answer is numeric
01114     } else {
01115         $correct_num_answer = $correctAnswer;
01116         $formattedCorrectAnswer = prfmt( $correctAnswer, $num_params{'format'} );
01117     }
01118 
01119     $correct_num_answer = math_constants($correct_num_answer);
01120 
01121     my $PGanswerMessage = '';
01122 
01123     my ($inVal,$correctVal,$PG_eval_errors,$PG_full_error_report);
01124 
01125     if (defined($correct_num_answer) && $correct_num_answer =~ /\S/ && $corrAnswerIsString == 0 )   {
01126             ($correctVal, $PG_eval_errors,$PG_full_error_report) = PG_answer_eval($correct_num_answer);
01127     } else { # case of a string answer
01128         $PG_eval_errors = ' ';
01129         $correctVal = $correctAnswer;
01130     }
01131 
01132     if ( ($PG_eval_errors && $corrAnswerIsString == 0) or ((not is_a_number($correctVal)) && $corrAnswerIsString == 0)) {
01133                 ##error message from eval or above
01134         warn "Error in 'correct' answer: $PG_eval_errors<br>
01135               The answer $correctAnswer evaluates to $correctVal,
01136               which cannot be interpreted as a number.  ";
01137 
01138     }
01139     #########################################################################
01140 
01141     #construct the answer evaluator
01142         my $answer_evaluator = new AnswerEvaluator;
01143         $answer_evaluator->{debug} = $num_params{debug};
01144         $answer_evaluator->ans_hash(
01145                             correct_ans             =>  $correctVal,
01146                             type                    =>  "${mode}_number",
01147                             tolerance               =>  $num_params{tolerance},
01148                             tolType                 =>  $num_params{tolType},
01149                             units                   =>  $correct_units,
01150                             original_correct_ans    =>  $formattedCorrectAnswer,
01151                             rh_correct_units        =>      \%correct_units,
01152                             answerIsString          =>  $corrAnswerIsString,
01153         );
01154         my ($in, $formattedSubmittedAnswer);
01155     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(sub {my $rh_ans = shift;
01156         $rh_ans->{original_student_ans} = $rh_ans->{student_ans}; $rh_ans;}
01157     );
01158 
01159     
01160 
01161     if (defined($num_params{units}) && $num_params{units}) {
01162             $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&check_units);
01163     }
01164     if (defined($num_params{strings}) && $num_params{strings}) {
01165             $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&check_strings, %num_params);
01166     }
01167     
01168     ## FIXME? - this pre filter was moved before check_units to allow
01169     ##      for latex preview of answers with no units.
01170     ##          seems to work but may have unintended side effects elsewhere.
01171     
01172     ##      Actually it caused trouble with the check strings package so it has been moved back
01173     #       We'll try some other method  -- perhaps add code to fix_answer for display
01174     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&check_syntax);
01175 
01176     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&math_constants);
01177 
01178     if ($mode eq 'std') {
01179                 # do nothing
01180     } elsif ($mode eq 'strict') {
01181         $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&is_a_number);
01182     } elsif ($mode eq 'arith') {
01183             $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&is_an_arithmetic_expression);
01184         } elsif ($mode eq 'frac') {
01185             $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&is_a_fraction);
01186 
01187         } elsif ($mode eq 'phase_pi') {
01188             $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&phase_pi);
01189 
01190         } else {
01191             $PGanswerMessage = 'Tell your professor that there is an error in his or her answer mechanism. No mode was specified.';
01192             $formattedSubmittedAnswer = $in;
01193         }
01194 
01195     if ($corrAnswerIsString == 0 ){     # avoiding running compare_numbers when correct answer is a string.
01196         $answer_evaluator->install_evaluator(\&compare_numbers, %num_params);
01197      }
01198 
01199 
01200 ###############################################################################
01201 # We'll leave these next lines out for now, so that the evaluated versions of the student's and professor's
01202 # can be displayed in the answer message.  This may still cause a few anomolies when strings are used
01203 #
01204 ###############################################################################
01205 
01206     $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(\&fix_answers_for_display);
01207 
01208         $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(sub {my $rh_ans = shift;
01209                     return $rh_ans unless $rh_ans->catch_error('EVAL');
01210                     $rh_ans->{student_ans} = $rh_ans->{original_student_ans}. ' '. $rh_ans->{error_message};
01211                     $rh_ans->clear_error('EVAL'); } );
01212         $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(sub {my $rh_ans = shift; $rh_ans->clear_error('SYNTAX'); } );
01213         $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(sub {my $rh_ans = shift; $rh_ans->clear_error('UNITS'); } );
01214         $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(sub {my $rh_ans = shift; $rh_ans->clear_error('NUMBER'); } );
01215         $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(sub {my $rh_ans = shift; $rh_ans->clear_error('STRING'); } );
01216         $answer_evaluator;
01217 }
01218
